Award.AwardTitle: Discovery-Based Student Learning with the Haystack 37-m Radio Telescope

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support the development of a national program of undergraduate STEM education through hands-on access to a world-class astronomical instrument. The program will expose students to a broad range of core science and engineering topics and techniques by means of direct participation in real-world research. The potency of curiosity-driven learning will be exploited to educate and motivate both future researchers and students destined for careers in industries that depend on core STEM competencies.

This project funds a 2-year pilot study to implement student research projects at the 37-meter radio telescope of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Haystack Observatory. During this pilot, a cost-effective remote observing capability for the antenna will be developed and tested, opening up access to the telescope to a diverse body of students from institutes of higher learning. Participation in this program will expose students and instructors to current problems in astronomy and astrophysics and allow the establishment of linkages between basic physics, mathematics, and engineering concepts and their application to solving real-world problems. Tutorials, instructional materials, and data reduction tools will be developed and improved with feedback from students and participating instructors. The student research carried out under this program will produce scientific data capable of advancing diverse areas of astrophysics, including astrochemistry, star formation, and stellar evolution. Examples of specific project topics include hydrogen recombination line spectra and astronomical masers. This program will provide an avenue to carry out original research to a wide range of students, including those at two-year colleges and non-research universities who do not presently have access to such opportunities. It will also provide an innovative means for college and university instructors to incorporate discovery-based research into STEM curricula. Educators of underrepresented groups have been recruited to participate, starting with the development and testing stages. Development work carried out under this project will provide opportunities for STEM students in the Research Experience for Undergraduates program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This program was conceived to develop and launch a program to enable hands-on learning by undergraduate students in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) using the newly refurbished 37m radio telescope at MIT Haystack Observatory.

The Haystack 37m antenna is owned by the United States Air Force and
operated by MIT Lincoln Laboratory for space situational awareness programs. However, one-third of the time on the antenna is available for astronomy research and education.

From 1998-2006, the Haystack antenna supported a program funded by the National Science Foundation that allowed undergraduate students to carry out remote observations from their classrooms and undertake original scientific investigations using the data.  The goal of the current award was to relaunch a similar program with the upgraded
antenna. However, practical considerations ultimately motivated a migration of the program to Haystack Observatory's Westford antenna.

While the refurbished 37m antenna is used regularly by the Air Force, the control systems, radiometers, backends, and other hardware and software required for astronomical measurements are independent and were not overhauled during the upgrade. Furthermore, the Air Force does not provide any direct funding or support for astronomy operations. Consequently, it was necessary to undertake significant development work to restore routine astronomy operations and accommodate student observing.

To keep the project within a modest budget, the project team repurposed components from the pre-upgrade antenna whenever possible, although to improve functionality and reliability, several components of the astronomy system were overhauled or replaced. Development activities included:

  • Updates to the antenna control interface
  • Installation of a new spectrometer
  • Commissioning of a new 3 mm radiometer
  • Redeployment and testing of the 7 mm and 1.3 cm radiometers
  • Characterize gain and pointing of the antenna.
  • Installation of a weather station
  • Creation of a database to record monitor/control and weather information.
  • Installation of a fiber link for signal transport.
  • Replacement of miscellaneous filters, power supplies, and cables.

Despite these efforts, the project suffered a series of significant setbacks owing to a combination of equipment failures, persistent equipment reliability issues, and loss of crucial project personnel. Consequently, a decision was made during Year 3 to shift the program to the Westford 18m geodetic antenna.

The manner in which the Westford antenna is operated and controlled is different in several ways from the Haystack antenna. This necessitated the development of new approaches and modifications to existing hardware and software. Examples included:

  • Hardware modifications to allow integration of the GPU spectrometer at Westford.
  • Development of a new approach to metadata collection.
  • Adaption to calibration using a noise diode.
  • Installation of a switch to disable the injection of pulse calibration signals.
  • Development of software to convert raw data to a standard format and join with its associated metadata (e.g., time of observation, antenna pointing coordinates, etc.).
  • Development of quicklook tools for real-time plotting and examination of data during observing.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

This project resulted in a new astronomical observing capability on
the Westford Radio Telescope. This capability will allow undergraduate students and professional astronomers to carry out original astronomical research with this antenna. It is anticipated that modified versions of the hardware and software developed for the Westford antenna will be ported to the Haystack 37m antenna in the future to enable similar capabilities on that antenna.

In addition to serving as a platform for carrying out original research by undergraduates, the new astronomy backend on the Westford antenna is expected to be useful for radio frequency interference monitoring and characterization---a rapidly growing challenge in radio astronomy.

The GPU spectrometer and its associated software that were developed here could provide a capable, low-cost spectrometer option for other observatories.

The quality of the data from this spectrometer has demonstrated
the promise of the Haystack facilities for enabling engaging and
original research projects by undergraduates.

BROADER IMPACTS

Undergraduates from several institutions were involved in aspects of this project from its inception, providing hands-on learning and training opportunities. Examples include:

  • A Cornell University student designed and tested a new GUI-based observing interface.
  • Two undergraduates from Morehead State University were involved in  characterization of the Haystack telescope frequency standard.
  • A student from the University of Minnesota-Morris designed a python-based tool to aid in observational planning.
  • A Union College spent a week at Haystack  to receive hands-on training with the Westford antenna (including  performing calibration measurements, planning observations, and data analysis).

Three educational modules were developed. These will be made publicly available and are intended to introduce faculty and students to radio astronomy and the capability of Haystack's telescopes.

During the course of the award, the Principal Investigator gave numerous tours of the Haystack 37m antenna to visiting students and other groups (including astronomy clubs, veterans groups, and senior citizens).  Co-investigators also gave lectures on radio astronomy to visiting students.

The awardees worked with an education professional to develop a survey to evaluate the learning and experiences of future student users of the Westford and 37m telescopes.
